member.name: P:Corvus.Json.PeriodBuilder.Item(NodaTime.PeriodUnits)
member.summary: Gets or sets the value of a single unit.

remarks.para: The type of this indexer is for uniformity, but any date unit (year, month, week, day) will only ever have a value in the range of .

For the unit, the value is converted to Int64 when reading from the indexer, causing it to fail if the value is out of range (around 250 years). To access the values of very large numbers of nanoseconds, use the property directly.

member.param: A single value within the enumeration.
member.value: The value of the given unit within this period builder, or zero if the unit is unset.
member.exception: is not a single unit, or a value is provided for a date unit which is outside the range of .

member.summary: Builds a period from the properties in this builder.
member.returns: The total number of nanoseconds in the period.

member.name: T:Corvus.Json.Period
member.summary: Represents a period of time expressed in human chronological terms: hours, days, weeks, months and so on.

remarks.para: A contains a set of properties such as , , and so on that return the number of each unit contained within this period. Note that these properties are not normalized in any way by default, and so a may contain values such as "2 hours and 90 minutes". The method will convert equivalent periods into a standard representation.

Periods can contain negative units as well as positive units ("+2 hours, -43 minutes, +10 seconds"), but do not differentiate between properties that are zero and those that are absent (i.e. a period created as "10 years" and one created as "10 years, zero months" are equal periods; the property returns zero in both cases).

equality is implemented by comparing each property's values individually, without any normalization. (For example, a period of "24 hours" is not considered equal to a period of "1 day".) The static comparer provides an equality comparer which performs normalization before comparisons.
There is no natural ordering for periods, but can be used to create a comparer which orders periods according to a reference date, by adding each period to that date and comparing the results.
Periods operate on calendar-related types such as whereas operates on instants on the time line. (Note that although includes both concepts, it only supports duration-based arithmetic.)

The complexity of each method in this type is hard to document precisely, and often depends on the calendar system involved in performing the actual calculations. Operations do not depend on the magnitude of the units in the period, other than for optimizations for values of zero or occasionally for particularly small values. For example, adding 10,000 days to a date does not require greater algorithmic complexity than adding 1,000 days to the same date.

member.threadsafety: This type is immutable reference type. See the thread safety section of the user guide for more information.

member.name: M:Corvus.Json.Period.CreateComparer(NodaTime.LocalDateTime)
member.summary: Creates an for periods, using the given "base" local date/time.
member.remarks: Certain periods can't naturally be compared without more context - how "one month" compares to "30 days" depends on where you start. In order to compare two periods, the returned comparer effectively adds both periods to the "base" specified by and compares the results. In some cases this arithmetic isn't actually required - when two periods can be converted to durations, the comparer uses that conversion for efficiency.
member.param: The base local date/time to use for comparisons.
member.returns: The new comparer.

The period to subtract the first operand from.
member.returns: The result of subtracting all the values in the second operand from the values in the first. The units of the result will be the union of both periods, even if the subtraction caused some properties to become zero (so "2 weeks, 1 days" minus "2 weeks" is "zero weeks, 1 days", not "1 days").

member.summary: Returns the number of days between two objects.
member.exception: and use different calendars.

member.name: M:Corvus.Json.Period.ToDuration
member.summary: For periods that do not contain a non-zero number of years or months, returns a duration for this period assuming a standard 7-day week, 24-hour day, 60-minute hour etc.
member.exception: The month or year property in the period is non-zero.

The period doesn't have years or months, but the calculation overflows the bounds of . In some cases this may occur even though the theoretical result would be valid due to balancing positive and negative values, but for simplicity there is no attempt to work around this - in realistic periods, it shouldn't be a problem.
member.returns: The duration of the period.

member.name: M:Corvus.Json.Period.Normalize
member.summary: Returns a normalized version of this period, such that equivalent (but potentially non-equal) periods are changed to the same representation.
member.remarks: Months and years are unchanged (as they can vary in length), but weeks are multiplied by 7 and added to the Days property, and all time properties are normalized to their natural range. Subsecond values are normalized to millisecond and "nanosecond within millisecond" values. So for example, a period of 25 hours becomes a period of 1 day and 1 hour. A period of 1,500,750,000 nanoseconds becomes 1 second, 500 milliseconds and 750,000 nanoseconds. Aside from months and years, either all the properties end up positive, or they all end up negative. "Week" and "tick" units in the returned period are always 0.
member.exception: The period doesn't have years or months, but it contains more than nanoseconds when the combined weeks/days/time portions are considered. This is over 292 years, so unlikely to be a problem in normal usage. In some cases this may occur even though the theoretical result would be valid due to balancing positive and negative values, but for simplicity there is no attempt to work around this.
member.returns: The normalized period.

member.name: M:Corvus.Json.Period.ToString
member.summary: Returns this string formatted according to the ISO8601 duration specification used by JSON schema.
member.returns: A formatted representation of this period.

member.name: T:Corvus.Json.UriTemplates.UriTemplate
member.summary: Implements a URI template conforming to http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6570, built over .

remarks.para: This is modelled on the Tavis.UriTemplate API, and offers mechanisms for parsing parameters from a URI according to a URI template and also resolving a template to a URI based on a provided set of parameters.

Note that this is not a low-allocation type. In particular, processing a URI template to create the template extraction parser is an expensive operation. If you do not need this functionality for a particular instance, you should ensure that you set the createParameterParser constructor parameter to .
For low-allocation scenarios you should use the low-level to create and cache an instance if you are doing parameter extraction. or use a if you are resolving a template from parameters.

member.name: M:Corvus.Json.UriTemplates.UriTemplate.#ctor(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Collections.Immutable.ImmutableDictionary{System.String,Corvus.Json.JsonAny})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct.
member.param: Whether to partially resolve the template.
Whether to use case insensitive parameter names.
Whether to pre-create the parameter extraction regex.

remarks.para: If you know this URI template is to be used purely for URI creation, not parameter extraction, then you should set to false. You will avoid creating and compiling a regular expression for parameter extraction.

member.name: M:Corvus.Json.ValidationContext.MergeResults(System.Boolean,Corvus.Json.ValidationLevel,Corvus.Json.ValidationContext@)
member.summary: Merge the messages for a given set of results into this result, applying the given validity at the end, regardless of the individual validity of the results in the set.
member.param: The ultimate validity of this context.
The current validation level for the context.
member.returns: The updated validation context.

remarks.para: Unlike , which merges the elements that were visited, this simply takes the contextual messages from the children, adds them to this context, and sets the validity as per the parameter.
This is typically used when one of a number of validations may be valid, and the ultimate result is some function of those child validations, but you wish to capture the details about the validation.

member.name: T:NodaTime.CalendarOrdinal
member.summary: Enumeration of calendar ordinal values. Used for converting between a compact integer representation and a calendar system. We use 6 bits to store the calendar ordinal in YearMonthDayCalendar, so we can have up to 64 calendars.

member.summary: Produces an array with "the sum of the elements of before the corresponding index". So for an input of [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5] this would produce [0, 0, 1, 3, 6, 10].

member.name: T:NodaTime.Calendars.RegularYearMonthDayCalculator
member.summary:
Subclass of YearMonthDayCalculator for calendars with the following attributes:
A fixed number of months
Occasional leap years which are always 1 day longer than non-leap years
The year starting with month 1, day 1 (i.e. naive YearMonthDay comparisons work)

member.name: T:NodaTime.Calendars.YearMonthDayCalculator
member.summary: The core of date calculations in Noda Time. This class *only* cares about absolute years, and only dates - it has no time aspects at all, nor era-related aspects.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Calendars.YearMonthDayCalculator.CalculateStartOfYearDays(System.Int32)
member.summary: Compute the start of the given year in days since 1970-01-01 ISO. The year may be outside the bounds advertised by the calendar, but only by a single year. This method is only called by (unless the calendar chooses to call it itself), so calendars which override that method and don't call the original implementation may leave this unimplemented (e.g. by throwing an exception if it's ever called).

member.name: M:NodaTime.Calendars.YearMonthDayCalculator.GetDaysInYear(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the number of days in the given year, which will always be within 1 year of the valid range for the calculator.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Calendars.YearMonthDayCalculator.MonthsBetween(NodaTime.YearMonthDay,NodaTime.YearMonthDay)
member.summary: Find the months between and . (If start is earlier than end, the result will be non-negative.)

member.name: M:NodaTime.Calendars.YearMonthDayCalculator.SetYear(NodaTime.YearMonthDay,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adjusts the given YearMonthDay to the specified year, potentially adjusting other fields as required.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Calendars.YearMonthDayCalculator.GetDaysSinceEpoch(NodaTime.YearMonthDay)
member.summary: Computes the days since the Unix epoch at the start of the given year/month/day. This is the opposite of . This assumes the parameter have been validated previously.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Calendars.YearMonthDayCalculator.GetStartOfYearInDays(System.Int32)
member.summary: Fetches the start of the year (in days since 1970-01-01 ISO) from the cache, or calculates and caches it.
member.param: The year to fetch the days at the start of. This must be within 1 year of the min/max range, but can exceed it to make week-year calculations simple.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Calendars.YearMonthDayCalculator.Compare(NodaTime.YearMonthDay,NodaTime.YearMonthDay)
member.summary: Compares two YearMonthDay values according to the rules of this calendar. The default implementation simply uses a naive comparison of the values, as this is suitable for most calendars (where the first month of the year is month 1).
member.remarks: Although the parameters are trusted (as in, they'll be valid in this calendar), the method being public isn't a problem - this type is never exposed.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Calendars.YearMonthDayCalculator.GetDayOfYear(NodaTime.YearMonthDay)

member.name: M:NodaTime.Calendars.YearMonthDayCalculator.GetYearMonthDay(System.Int32)
member.summary: Works out the year/month/day of a given days-since-epoch by first computing the year and day of year, then getting the month and day from those two. This is how almost all calendars are naturally implemented anyway.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Calendars.YearMonthDayCalculator.GetYear(System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Work out the year from the number of days since the epoch, as well as the day of that year (0-based).

member.name: T:NodaTime.Calendars.YearStartCacheEntry
member.summary: Type containing as much logic as possible for how the cache of "start of year" data works. As of Noda Time 1.3, this is not specific to YearMonthDayCalculator - it can be used for other frames of reference, so long as they comply with the restrictions listed below.

remarks.para: Each entry in the cache is a 32-bit number. The "value" part of the entry consists of the number of days since the Unix epoch (negative for a value before the epoch). As Noda Time only supports a number of ticks since the Unix epoch of between long.MinValue and long.MaxValue, we only need to support a number of days in the range [long.MinValue / TicksPerDay, long.MaxValue / TicksPerDay] which is [-10675200, 10675200] (rounding away from 0). This value can be stored in 25 bits.

The remaining 7 bits of the value are used for validation. For any given year, the bottom 10 bits are used as the index into the cache (which is an array). The next 7 most significant bits are stored in the entry. So long as we have fewer than 17 significant bits in the year value, this will be a unique combination. A single validation value (the most highly positive value) is reserved to indicate an invalid entry. The cache is initialized with all entries invalid. This gives us a range of year numbers greater than [-60000, 60000] without any risk of collisions. By contrast, the ISO calendar years are in the range [-27255, 31195] - so we'd have to be dealing with a calendar with either very short years, or an epoch a long way ahead or behind the Unix epoch.

The fact that each cache entry is only 32 bits means that we can safely use the cache from multiple threads without locking. 32-bit aligned values are guaranteed to be accessed atomically, so we know we'll never get the value for one year with the validation bits for another, for example.

member.name: F:NodaTime.Calendars.YearStartCacheEntry.Invalid
member.summary: Entry which is guaranteed to be obviously invalid for any real date, by having a validation value which is larger than any valid year number.

member.name: F:NodaTime.Calendars.YearStartCacheEntry.value
member.summary: Entry value: most significant 25 bits are the number of days (e.g. since the Unix epoch); remaining 7 bits are the validator.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Calendars.YearStartCacheEntry.GetValidator(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the validator to use for a given year, a non-negative number containing at most EntryValidationBits bits.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Calendars.YearStartCacheEntry.GetCacheIndex(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the cache index, in [0, CacheSize), that should be used to store the given year's cache entry.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Calendars.YearStartCacheEntry.IsValidForYear(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns whether this cache entry is valid for the given year, and so is safe to use. (We assume that we have located this entry via the correct cache index.)

member.name: P:NodaTime.Calendars.YearStartCacheEntry.StartOfYearDays
member.summary: Returns the (signed) number of days since the Unix epoch for the cache entry.

member.name: T:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor
member.summary: Provides a cursor over text being parsed. None of the methods in this class throw exceptions (unless there is a bug in Noda Time, in which case an exception is appropriate) and none of the methods have ref parameters indicating failures, unlike subclasses. This class is used as the basis for both value and pattern parsing, so can make no judgement about what's wrong (i.e. it wouldn't know what type of failure to indicate). Instead, methods return Boolean values to indicate success or failure.

member.name: F:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.Nul
member.summary: A nul character. This character is not allowed in any parsable string and is used to indicate that the current character is not set.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance to parse the given value.
member.param: The value on which to base the cursor.

member.summary: Gets the length of the string being parsed.

member.name: P:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.Value
member.summary: Gets the string being parsed.

member.name: P:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.Current
member.summary: Gets the current character.

member.name: P:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.HasMoreCharacters
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this instance has more characters.
member.value: true if this instance has more characters; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.Index
member.summary: Gets the current index into the string being parsed.

member.name: P:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.Remainder
member.summary: Gets the remainder the string that has not been parsed yet.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.ToString
member.summary: Returns a that represents this instance.
member.returns: A that represents this instance.

member.summary: Peek the next character.
member.returns: Returns the next character if there is one or if there isn't.

member.summary: Moves the specified target index. If the new index is out of range of the valid indices for this string then the index is set to the beginning or the end of the string whichever is nearest the requested index.
member.returns: true if the requested index is in range.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.MoveNext
member.summary: Moves to the next character.
member.returns: true if the requested index is in range.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.MovePrevious
member.summary: Moves to the previous character.
member.returns: true if the requested index is in range.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.Match(System.Char)
member.summary: Attempts to match the specified character with the current character of the string. If the character matches then the index is moved passed the character.
member.returns: true if the character matches.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.Match(System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Char})
member.summary: Attempts to match the specified string with the current point in the string. If the character matches then the index is moved past the string.
member.returns: true if the string matches.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.MatchCaseInsensitive(System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Char},System.Globalization.CompareInfo,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Attempts to match the specified string with the current point in the string in a case-insensitive manner, according to the given comparison info. The cursor is optionally updated to the end of the match.
member.returns: True if there is a case-insensitive match.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.CompareOrdinal(System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Char})
member.summary: Compares the value from the current cursor position with the given match. If the given match string is longer than the remaining length, the comparison still goes ahead but the result is never 0: if the result of comparing to the end of the value returns 0, the result is -1 to indicate that the value is earlier than the given match. Conversely, if the remaining value is longer than the match string, the comparison only goes as far as the end of the match. So "xabcd" with the cursor at "a" will return 0 when matched with "abc".
member.param: The value with which to match.
member.returns: A negative number if the value (from the current cursor position) is lexicographically earlier than the given match string; 0 if they are equal (as far as the end of the match) and a positive number if the value is lexicographically later than the given match string.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.ParseInt64(System.Int64@)
member.summary: Parses digits at the current point in the string as a signed 64-bit integer value. Currently this method only supports cultures whose negative sign is "-" (and using ASCII digits).
member.param: The result integer value. The value of this is not guaranteed to be anything specific if the return value is non-null.
member.returns: if the value was parsed successfully.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.ParseInt64Digits(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int64@)
member.summary: Parses digits at the current point in the string, as an value. If the minimum required digits are not present then the index is unchanged. If there are more digits than the maximum allowed they are ignored.
member.param: The result integer value. The value of this is not guaranteed to be anything specific if the return value is false.
member.returns: true if the digits were parsed.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.ParseDigits(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Parses digits at the current point in the string. If the minimum required digits are not present then the index is unchanged. If there are more digits than the maximum allowed they are ignored.
member.param: The result integer value. The value of this is not guaranteed to be anything specific if the return value is false.
member.returns: true if the digits were parsed.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.ParseFraction(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses digits at the current point in the string as a fractional value.
member.param: The maximum allowed digits. Trusted to be less than or equal to scale.
The scale of the fractional value.
The result value scaled by scale. The value of this is not guaranteed to be anything specific if the return value is false.
The minimum number of digits that must be specified in the value.
member.returns: true if the digits were parsed.

member.name: M:NodaTime.Text.ValueCursor.GetDigit
member.summary: Gets the integer value of the current digit character, or -1 for "not a digit".
member.remarks: This currently only handles ASCII digits, which is all we have to parse to stay in line with the BCL.

member.name: T:NodaTime.YearMonthDay
member.summary: A compact representation of a year, month and day in a single 32-bit integer.

remarks.para: See for the number of bits per component, but this doesn't have the calendar component, so bit 0 is part of the day value. This type is naive: comparisons are performed assuming that a larger month number always comes after a smaller month number, etc. This is suitable for most, but not all, calendar systems.
The internal representation actually uses 0 for 1 (etc) for each component. That means the default value is 0001-01-01, which is reasonable for all supported calendars.

member.name: M:NodaTime.YearMonthDay.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a new value for the given year, month and day. No validation is performed.

member.name: T:NodaTime.YearMonthDayCalendar
member.summary: A compact representation of a year, month and day and calendar ordinal (integer ID) in a single 32-bit integer.

remarks.para:
The calendar is represented in bits 0-5. The day is represented in bits 6-11. The month is represented in bits 12-16. The year is represented in bits 17-31. (It's convenient to put this at the top as it can be negative.)
This type does not implement IComparable[YearMonthDayCalendar] as it turns out it doesn't need to: comparisons are always done through the calendar system, which uses YearMonthDay instead. We could potentially optimize by bypassing the calendar and embedding knowledge of calendars which have "odd" month numberings in here, but it would be a bit of a design smell.
Equality is easily tested, however, as it can check for calendar equality.
The internal representation actually uses 0 for 1 (etc) for each component. That means the default value is 0001-01-01, which is reasonable for all supported calendars.

member.name: M:NodaTime.YearMonthDayCalendar.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,NodaTime.CalendarOrdinal)
member.summary: Constructs a new value for the given year, month, day and calendar. No validation is performed.
